awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  ABI Development:  Building a Pipeline for Validation, Curation and Archiving of Integrative/Hybrid Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in the field of structural biology have led to the elucidation of the three-dimensional structures of very large macromolecular machines of high biological impact using novel "integrative/hybrid" (I/H) methods. These leading-edge I/H methods integrate information from different sources to determine the structures of complex biomolecular assemblies, analogous to assembling the pieces of a puzzle to build a three-dimensional object. Some of the landmark structures determined using I/H methods include the nuclear pore complex that enables the transport of proteins across the nuclear membrane and the proteasomal lid sub-complex that regulates the degradation of damaged, malfunctioning or toxic proteins in the cell. There is currently no repository capable of archiving these I/H structures so that they are available for downstream scientific and biomedical applications. The current project builds a comprehensive software pipeline to support the validation, curation and dissemination of I/H models so that they are freely available to the broader community. The outcomes of this project will make key structures of biological assemblies accessible to researchers, educators and students around the world. This project will impact scientists who use structural biology data for their research as well as students and educators who study the role of structure in biology. This research will directly and significantly enhance the field of biology and medicine and extend its impact on the broader community through education and outreach activities. 

This project extends a previously developed prototype system (PDB-Dev) by building the complete data pipeline for the curation, validation and delivery of I/H models. This will be achieved through the creation of an automated deposition system to support a broad range of I/H models; development of annotation and validation pipelines for processing I/H models by leveraging existing protocols and tools; development of new tools for visualizing multi-scale model representations and model uncertainly; creation of a service architecture to manage data exchange among federated resources capable of supporting evolutionary improvements of I/H models and associated experimental data; and development of a delivery platform to support data set discovery and to provide web services for searching, reporting, and data download. Since I/H methods integrate information from several experimental and computational techniques, this project also prototypes a new centralized software environment that facilitates automated communication and exchange of data among a federation of structural biology model and data repositories contributing to I/H modeling. These developments will lead to a robust system capable to archiving and disseminating I/H models to the public in a standard form. The results of the project will be available on the PDB-Dev website at https://pdb-dev.wwpdb.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

por.por_cntn:
Increasingly, structures of many complex biological systems are determined using integrative modeling approaches that involve combining data from multiple experimental and computational methods to build the structures of complex macromolecular assemblies. We have built a standalone prototype system, called PDB-Dev (https://pdb-dev.wwpdb.org), for archiving integrative structures and making them publicly available. The current project was focused on developing a comprehensive software infrastructure to support the deposition, biocuration, validation, visualization, and dissemination of integrative structures through the PDB-Dev system. This project has addressed a timely need in the evolving field of structural biology and ensures that integrative structures are made publicly available according to the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) guiding principles of scientific data stewardship. 

The significant outcomes of this research project are: 

1. Expanded set of data standards for representing spatiotemporally and conformationally diverse integrative structures (https://github.com/ihmwg/IHM-dictionary, https://mmcif.wwpdb.org/dictionaries/mmcif_ihm.dic/Index/). These standards are extended from existing standards used by the Protein Data Bank (PDB) to archive experimentally-derived structures (https://github.com/wwpdb-dictionaries/mmcif_pdbx, https://mmcif.wwpdb.org/dictionaries/mmcif_pdbx_v50.dic/Index/) and thus facilitate interoperation with PDB data. 

2. Software tools that support the expanded set of data standards (https://github.com/ihmwg/python-ihm) and enable adoption of these standards in the scientific community. 

3. A deposition and data harvesting system (https://data.pdb-dev.org/) that facilitates the collection and processing of heterogeneous data associated with integrative structures. 

4. Methods for biocuration, validation (https://github.com/salilab/IHMValidation), and visualization of integrative structures that enable data processing, standardization, and quality estimation. 

5. A platform for data dissemination (https://pdb-dev.wwpdb.org) that provides web services and tools for searching, retrieving, browsing, report generation, visualization, dataset discovery, and data download. 

This project has enabled the creation of a data pipeline for deposition, biocuration, archiving, validation, dissemination, and visualization of integrative structures. It is important to recognize that before the creation of PDB-Dev, no mechanisms were available to archive any of these results. The project has also consistently demonstrated the value of involving the scientific community and using community consensus in creating data standards and methods for archiving and validation of structural biology data.  

PDB-Dev has made key structures of biological assemblies freely available to researchers, educators, and students around the world. PDB-Dev currently consists of more than 100 released structures and more than 30 structures that are either on hold for publication or are being processed. PDB-Dev has enabled archiving integrative structures of large, complex, and dynamic macromolecular networks and machinery that drive fundamental biological processes such as replication, transcription, translation, genomic regulation, DNA repair, protein degradation, movement of proteins across the nuclear membrane, and immune response. In addition to structural data, PDB-Dev also includes input spatial restraint data used in the modeling as well as information regarding kinetics and dynamics obtained from biophysical methods. PDB-Dev thus promotes the FAIR principles and impacts scientists and educators who use structural biology models and data for their research. 

With recent breakthroughs in computational biology leading to the successful application of machine learning algorithms to build computed structure models of macromolecules, integrative structural biology is entering a new phase, where the starting structures of macromolecular components of large assemblies are readily available. Experimental techniques that provide restraint information to assemble components of biomolecular complexes can now use these starting models to build integrative structures of assemblies on a large scale. We have already started receiving integrative structures that use computed structure models from AlphaFold as starting models and are looking forward to more depositions that use experimental data and starting computational models to build integrative structures of complex macromolecular assemblies. Biophysical methods that carry information regarding the dynamics of these assemblies can provide additional insights into their function. Creating a rigorous standardized process for deposition, curation, validation, archival, and dissemination of integrative structures empowers the scientific community to tackle very large structure determination challenges such as elucidation of the three-dimensional structures of complete genomes and even the creation of a spatiotemporal model of an entire cell.

The outcomes of this project ensure that the results of integrative structural biology investigations are archived appropriately and made available to the scientific community and the general public for utilization towards the advancement of worldwide education, healthcare, and research. Specifically, open access to integrative structures of macromolecular systems greatly enhances the understanding of biomolecular structure and function, thus catalyzing the progress of biological and biomedical research. In addition, the project enables a growing user community to study and understand molecular function at the structural level in areas ranging from cellular and molecular biology to nanotechnology and biomolecular design. 


Last Modified: 12/16/2022
Modified by: Brinda Vallat
